title: Rabbit Grooming 101
content:
Grooming

How to Trim Your Rabbit’s Nails

  1. Gather Supplies
    You'll need small animal nail clippers, styptic powder (in case of bleeding), a towel, and good lighting. Optional: a helper to gently hold your bunny.

  2. Get Your Bunny Comfortable
    Find a calm, quiet space. Wrap your rabbit securely in a towel like a bunny burrito, leaving one paw exposed. This helps prevent sudden movements and keeps them feeling safe.

  3. Identify the Quick
    Hold the paw up to the light to locate the pink vein (quick) inside each nail. Avoid cutting into the quick—it’s painful and will bleed.

title: What to do: GI Stasis
content:
GI Stasis

What to Do Right Now

  1. Know the condition
    GI stasis = slowed/paused movement of food through the gut. It isn’t just hairballs; it’s often triggered by illness (dental, kidney), stress/pain/heat, or a low-fiber, high-carb diet. When rabbits stop eating, gut pH shifts and gas-producing bacteria bloom—causing painful gas and toxins. Treat this as urgent.

  2. See a vet promptly
    Vets confirm with exam + X-rays (often gas-filled stomach/cecum) and bloodwork (dehydration/electrolytes). They may check teeth for points/abscesses. Treatment typically includes fluids for rehydration, syringe feeding for nutrition, pain control, anti-inflammatories, and—when the rabbit is producing stool—motility drugs. Antibiotics are used if there’s a bacterial infection. Hospitalization may be recommended depending on severity.

  3. Prevent recurrence
    Feed a hay-based, high-fiber diet with leafy greens; limit pellets to about 1 tbsp per kg of ideal body weight per day. Remove calorie-dense treats; keep fruit rare. Reduce pellets gradually over a week (no crash dieting), add daily supervised exercise/enrichment, and keep the bottom clean while weight comes off. Ask your vet/vet nurse for a personalized plan and regular checks.

title: How to Bond Rabbits
content:
Bunny Bonding Basics

A calm, step-by-step approach

  1. Prep & timing
    Have both rabbits spayed/neutered before introductions. Wait 2–4 weeks post-surgery for healing and hormones to settle (males may remain fertile up to six weeks). Set up a neutral space that neither bun claims. Gather gloves/towel, a spray bottle to pre-empt scuffles, and keep first sessions short (5–15 min).

  2. First sessions in neutral territory
    Use spaces unlike the resident bun’s area (bathroom, empty tub, friend’s home, garage, or a pen in a new room). Keep areas controllable with no trap corners. Start side-by-side housing in separate enclosures placed near each other so they can see/smell without contact.

  3. Read behaviors & guide gently
    Tentative friendship (sniffing, sitting near) is common. Mounting can be normal dominance as long as the submissive rabbit tolerates it—ensure faces are visible to avoid bites. Brief chasing may occur; watch closely and interrupt before escalation (quick spritz or a calm reset). Avoid full fights; negative events can set bonding back. If needed, short, mildly novel experiences (e.g., laundry basket on a running dryer or a short car ride) can help them associate each other with safety.

  4. Progress, setbacks, and aftercare
    Work daily for at least 15 minutes; increase duration as tolerance improves. Expect ups and downs. Until fully bonded, keep them separate when unsupervised. Once bonded, do not separate—take both to the vet together so scent/health changes don’t trigger rejection. Give equal attention, avoid favorites, and end sessions on a positive note whenever possible.

title: Is my bunny obese?
content:
Is Your Rabbit Too Fat?

How to assess and fix weight safely

  1. Why extra weight matters
    Pet rabbits often get more treats and less exercise than wild rabbits. Excess weight strains the heart, worsens arthritis, and makes self-grooming hard. A dirty backside can lead to flystrike in warm weather—an emergency. Take weight concerns seriously.

  2. Check body condition (BCS 1–5)
    Feel—don’t just look. You should feel ribs under a firm muscle layer (like a pocket of pens), not sharp like rulers (too thin) and not buried (too fat). Big dewlaps, fat pads, pot belly, or looking wider than long suggest overweight. Ideal is BCS 3/5.

  3. Healthy plan & prevention
    Switch to a hay-based, high-fiber diet with daily greens; limit pellets to about 1 tbsp per kg of ideal body weight per day. Remove calorie-dense treats; keep fruit rare. Reduce pellets gradually over a week, add daily exercise/enrichment, and keep the bottom clean while weight comes off. Ask your vet/vet nurse for a personalized plan and regular checks.
